name: Croton
plantingInfo: When choosing a container, be aware that the plant grows upright and may eventually become top heavy.
Use potting soil that drains well. Croton thrive when moist, not wet.
In warm and humid climates, Crotons can be grown outdoors. When the temperatures drop to around 50°F, bring them inside.
careInfo: Crotons prefer it sunny, so place in a window with plenty of light. If it isn't getting enough light, newer leaves will be dull in color.
Soil should be moist, and should be dried out before rewatering.
If humidity is low, mist the leaves once a week, or keep a tray of wet gravel near the plant.
Wipe the leaves with a damp cloth a couple times a month as Croton leaves can attract dust.
New plants can be propagated from 4- to 6-inch stem clippings.
In the spring, replant if the croton is too large for it's pot.

name: Dracaena
blurbInfo: Tolerates full sun to partial shade
plantingInfo: When choosing a container, be aware that the plant grows upright.
Use potting soil that drains well. Soil should never be soggy.
Dracaena is sensitive to fluoride, so use purified water.
careInfo: Filtered indoor light is best for dracaena, but a semi-shade spot works as well.
Never place dracaena in direct sunlight or the rays will scorch the foliage.
Dracaena require less water than most houseplants, hydrate by misting leaves and soil with water.
Temperatures below 55°F will harm the plant.
Wiping dust off the leaves once or twice a week will help the plant absorb oxygen.
